results.title: Japan: a profile of the nation today
results.brief_description: A general view of life in Japan today, touching briefly on the many aspects of industry, society, traditional ways and modern developments throughout the whole of the country.

results.title: Japan nearby
results.brief_description: A young woman doing research for her thesis on Japan - Australia Relations and a young man interested in architecture, share some of their knowledge and ideas with the audience while showing them aspects of traditional and modern Japanese life both in Australia and Japan.

results.title: Japan inc: lessons for North America?
results.creator_credit: Kalle Lasn, John Coney, John Taylor, Peter Jones and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: Organization, discipline and productivity in Japan are on a scale not known in any other country of the world. For the 110 million people of Japan, survival means doing things together—a concept that has seen that nation automate and computerize at an unparalleled rate. Just how this level of achievement was reached is the subject of this absorbing documentary study of Japanese business and industry.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Kalle Lasn, John Coney, John Taylor, Peter Jones and ONF | NFB

results.title: Japan's surrender
results.brief_description: Documentary profiling the USA’s victory over Japan through atomic warfare during World War II and their eventual surrender signifying the end of the War. Edited by Eugene W. Castle.

results.title: Japan's art from the land
results.creator_credit: Hugh Gage, Holt, Rinehart and Winston and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: The famous artist Shuson Kono, paints a mountain landscape capturing the serenity of nature in the still muted-toned ponds that border the Katsura, the 17th century Imperial Palace. Bamboo flutes and vocal chorus intensify the deeply reflective mood of this poetic film. Also includes images of rural Japan and illustrates the designing of various Japanese gardens.

results.title: Janus. Eps 25 and 26: Mute by visitation. Elements of murder
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 25 and 26 of the television series Janus. “Mute by visitation” (50 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith). Glenda de Bono is listed to preside as Judge on a retrial of a rape case. This is her first major trial since becoming a County Judge. The unusual aspect of this trial however, is that both the victim, Colleen Maitland (Danni Wright) and the alleged rapist, Tim Lester (Mike Canfield) are profoundly deaf - so are their families and the witnesses. Meanwhile, application for Mal Hennessey’s blood sample for DNA testing is granted and Peter Faithful gets a bonus when “Gazza”, during his interview, puts Shirl Hennessey in the picture as the one to organise the disposal of Patrick Clancy’s body. “Elements of murder” (51 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) is the final episode of Janus. Mal Hennessey and Shirl Hennessey face a commital hearing - Mal for murder and Shirl for accessory after the fact to murder. The use of DNA as corroborating material, and Sandy (Mal’s ex girlfriend), Gazza and Tomlinson as witnesses for the Prosecution, make it almost impossible for Michael Kidd to get Mal and Shirl off. And the internal investigation into Steve Hennessey’s death is closing in on Peter Faithful and his team. A dramatic conclusion to this brilliant Australian television series. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Louise Siversen, Brett Swain, Paulene Terry-Beitz, Leverne McDonnell, Belinda McClory and Victoria Eagger.

results.title: Janus. Eps 23 and 24: Breach of bond. An Unnatural act
results.creator_credit: Julian McSwiney, Robert Klenner, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 23 and 24 of the television series Janus. “Breach of bond” (48 mins) (directed by Robert Klenner). Shane Hennessey (Jonathan Kernut) has broken his 12 month bond and finds himself remanded in custody on charges of robbery causing injury intentionally, theft and possession of a drug of dependence. Once again he faces Glenda de Bono (Louise Siversen), the same magistrate who put him on a bond for his previous offences. Glenda de Bono also hears a case against a family of gypsies involving crystal balls, curses and large payments of cash. “An Unnatural act” (50 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney) focuses on a disturbing case of incest where a father has allegedly raped his 10-year-old daughter. Michael Kidd acts as Defence Counsellor for the father with Tina Bertrum prosecuting on behalf of the daughter, Evie (Leah de Niese). Meanwhile an escaped prisoner who has been recaptured could be Peter Faithful’s answer to the final missing link in the murder case against Mal Hennessey. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Tracy Mann, Paulene Terry-Beitz, and Ezra Bix.

results.title: Janus. Eps 21 and 22: Demands with menaces. Fit to plead
results.creator_credit: Kate Woods, Mandy Smith, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 21 and 22 of the television series Janus. “Demands with menaces” (50 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith) finds Peter Faithful in the hot seat again. Rhonda Hennessey’s (Victoria Eagger) husband, Darren Mack (Nique Needles) is to stand trial at a committal hearing for attempted extortion on a fellow inmate at Pentridge. Allegations are made about Peter Faithful’s involvement with the victim, Zoglin (Raj Sidhu) at the police interview and Faithful offering support to Zoglin in a bail application. Michael Kidd argues on the premise of the Hennessey connection, that Darren Mack is part of the Hennessey family and subsequently a target for Peter Faithful’s ongoing investigation into the Hennessey’s. “Fit to plead” (52 mins) (directed by Kate Woods) follows two separate court scenarios. One involving Darren Mack attending his sentencing hearing and the other, an Aboriginal prisoner, Ray Crundall (David Ngoombujarra) being tried for assault. Defence Counsellor, Kathy Tainsh (Glenda Linscott) finds herself fighting the system for justice and understanding on behalf of her Aboriginal client, and Darren Mack decides to fight the system himself, sacking his Defence Counsellor and going it alone. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Felix Nobis, Steve Hardman, Tracy Mann, and Alex Scott.

results.title: Janus. Eps 19 and 20: Confess and avoid. A Prima facie case
results.creator_credit: Robert Klenner, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 19 and 20 of the television series Janus. “Confess and avoid” (48 mins) (directed by Robert Klenner) literally means confess to the lesser charges and hopefully avoid the serious charge. Michael Kidd has not lost a case in eight years but doubts start to set in when he finds himself defending a young law student, Ian Bisley (Richard Sutherland) who has been charged with culpable driving. Jenny Hanson (Jane Menelaus) as representative for the Crown Prosecution at the same time, is not looking forward to doing battle with the formidable Michael Kidd. “A Prima facie case” (48 mins) (directed by Julian McSwiney). Witnesses are called to give evidence at the commital hearing into Steve Hennessey’s death. Allegations are being made that Peter Faithful covered up for his mates and conflicting versions by the witnesses as to whether Steve Hennessey was armed, only complicates matters further. Peter Faithful decides to confront Michael Kidd’s allegations of persecution and corruption by taking the witness stand. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Louise Siversen, Felix Nobis, Tamsin West, David Bradshaw and Steve Vidler.
results.title_for_label: Janus. Eps 19 and 20: Confess and avoid. A Prima facie case
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robert Klenner, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Janus. Eps 17 and 18: Right to remain silent. My learned friend, Mr Hennessey
results.creator_credit: Mandy Smith, Michael Carson, Bill Hughes and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Janus”.
Episodes 17 and 18 of the television series Janus. “Right to remain silent” (51 mins) (directed by Mandy Smith). The internal investigation into the shooting of Steve Hennessey continues. Meantime, Roz Breen (Jeanette Cronin) who has been charged with smuggling drugs into prison, decides to fight the case. Her defence is “duress”, caused by intimidation and fear of the Hennessey family. Although Steve is dead, the drug trafficking connection still lives on. “My learned friend, Mr Hennessey” (52 mins) (directed by Michael Carson) shows Mal Hennessey (Brett Swain) in a somewhat different light to the usual cold, indifferent violent person that he can be, as he defends himself in a commital hearing on a charge of “Breach of prison” relating to his escape from the Police Van. With Shirl Hennessey still in Fairlea and no money to pay Michael Kidd to defend him, Mal has to take on the system. And take on the system he does, much to Vic Manoulis’s frustration and Peter Faithful’s growing concern. Contains some scenes in b&w. Cast also includes Chris Haywood, Simon Westaway, Jeremy Kewley, Felix Nobis, Leverne McDonnell, Simon Chilvers, Paul Gleeson.
